entry.title: The Latest: Theater shooting survivor says she has closure
entry.summary: Colorado theater shooting survivor Jansen Young says she finally has closure with the guilty verdict against shooter James Holmes.

entry.title: The Latest: Theater shooting survivor says she has closure
entry.summary: Colorado theater shooter James Holmes is showing no visible reaction as the judge reads the jury's verdict on all 165 counts against him.

entry.title: Timeline of events leading to guilty verdicts in Colorado theater shooting case
entry.summary:
Dec. 13, 1987 - Holmes is born in San Diego County, California, to Robert and Arlene Holmes.

2011 - Holmes enrolls in the Ph.D. neuroscience program at the University of Colorado's Anschutz Medical Campus in the Denver suburb of Aurora.

February 2012 - Holmes and Gargi Datta break off their relationship.

July 20, 2012 - Holmes slips through a back door of the Century 16 theater in Aurora, where about 420 people are watching a midnight showing of a Batman movie, "The Dark Knight Rises," and opens fire.

entry.title: Colorado theatre shooter James Holmes guilty of murder
entry.summary: Centennial, Colorado: A US jury has found Colorado theatre shooter James Holmes guilty of murder for the attack that left 12 dead and dozens wounded.

entry.title: Batman shooter trial: James Holmes verdict - live
entry.summary: If Holmes is convicted of first degree murder, a decision to spare his life in the penalty phase would result in a mandatory life sentence without the possibility of parole.

entry.title: Batman shooter trial: James Holmes verdict - live
entry.summary: If the jury agrees that Holmes was insane, he would avoid execution and likely spend the rest of his life committed to the state's mental hospital in Pueblo, 100 miles (160 km) south of Denver.

entry.title: Jurors reach verdict in trial of Colorado movie gunman
entry.summary:
The jury in the Colorado movie massacre trial reached a verdict on Thursday, the second day of deliberations in the case of 27-year-old gunman James Holmes, who has pleaded not guilty by reason of insanity, a court spokesman said.

Holmes did not testify in his own defense, but jurors watched video of some 23 hours of interviews conducted with him by one of the court-appointed psychiatrists.

entry.title: Verdict reached against Colorado theater gunman James Holmes
entry.summary: Prosecutors honed in on Holmes' elaborate planning of the massacre.

entry.title: James Holmes' trial: A look at key aspects as closings begin
entry.summary:
Holmes surrendered to police outside the theater.

They also examined scores of pieces of evidence, including Holmes' guns and ammunition.

entry.title: Lawyers in theater shooting trial make final appeals to jury
entry.summary: Jurors in the Colorado theater shooting case soon will retreat into the largest jury room in the courthouse to determine whether Holmes was legally insane at the time of the killing spree.

entry.title: Lawyers in theater shooting trial make final appeals to jury
entry.summary: King pleaded with jurors to believe that Holmes' mental illness was the sole cause of the attack.

entry.title: Colorado shooting defendant James Holmes called ‘psychotic’ by his attorney
entry.summary:
Daniel King said Holmes had been mentally ill even before the 2012 attack on the movie theater in Aurora, Colo., and urged the jurors to look beyond how the gunman planned his attack.

The prosecution had earlier argued that the deliberate nature of the planning and execution of the attack showed that Holmes was not mentally ill.

entry.title: After all is said in theater attack trial, was Holmes sane?
entry.summary: A copy of Colorado's insanity statute will guide them in the jury room as they consider Holmes' mental state that night, analyzing his medical records, family history, police reports and journal.

entry.title: After all is said in theater attack trial, was Holmes sane?
entry.summary:
The only question they must answer is whether Holmes met Colorado's threshold for an insanity verdict, by suffering from mental illness so severe that it rendered him unable to tell right from wrong at the time of the shootings.

The hideous details of the attack, the heartbreaking survival stories, the signs of mental illness that Holmes showed well before the events of July 20, 2012 - they shouldn't matter.

If they agree Holmes is insane, he would be committed indefinitely to a state mental hospital.

entry.title: Doctor who found Holmes insane didn't watch much of video
entry.summary:
Dr. Jonathan Woodcock, one of the first defense witnesses to take the stand, interviewed Holmes four days after the July 20, 2012, shooting to determine if he was competent to stand trial and then again earlier this year when he was asked by the defense to testify on Holmes' sanity.

He said Holmes was so delusional and psychotic as a result of deep-seeded mental illness that he was unable to tell right from wrong when he opened fire on the theater - Colorado's standard for an insanity verdict.

Brauchler pointed out that Woodcock didn't talk to Holmes about the crime or his plans for the shooting in either interview and already completed a report concluding he was insane before the second, one-hour interview.

But, pressed further by defense attorney Daniel King, Woodcock said he reviewed Reid's report based on the interview and many other records and evidence and did not find anything that would have changed his own conclusion about Holmes.

entry.title: The Latest: Doctor says Holmes insane at time of shooting
entry.summary: Defense attorneys for Holmes are preparing to open their case on Thursday, June 25, 2015 with witnesses they hope can illustrate the severity of his mental illness at the time of the attack on July 20, 2012.

entry.title: Doctor who found Holmes insane didn't watch much of video
entry.summary: Brauchler suggested that jurors and others in the courtroom who had watched all 22 hours of Dr. William Reid's interview, in which Holmes talked at length about his planning and preparation for the shooting, had observed him longer than Woodcock had.

entry.title: Doctor Who Found Holmes Insane Didn't Watch Much of Video
entry.summary: In response to their inquiries, Woodcock reaffirmed his conclusion that Holmes was insane.

entry.title: The Latest: Doctor says Holmes insane at time of shooting
entry.summary:
A psychiatrist who determined that Colorado theater shooter James Holmes was insane at the time of the 2012 shootings says that people suffering from delusions can't always control behavior - even if they know the behavior is wrong.

Dr. Jonathan Woodcock interviewed Holmes four days after the attack and concluded that he wasn't sane.

Woodcock testified Thursday that Holmes had a strong family history of mental illness and was in the grip of a psychotic compulsion he could not control.

Jonathan Woodcock said Holmes' emotions also were extremely flat.

That kind of reaction in the wake of the mass shooting helped Woodcock conclude that Holmes was suffering from significant mental illness.

Jonathan Woodcock is an assistant professor of neurology and psychiatry at the University of Colorado's medical campus, the school where James Holmes was studying before the July 2012 attack.

Prosecutors in the Colorado theater shooting are questioning whether one of the defense's most important witnesses - a psychiatrist who interviewed James Holmes - should be considered an expert.

entry.title: Wendell Holmes, singer, songwriter of Holmes Brothers, dies
entry.summary:
Wendell Holmes, the guitarist, pianist and singer and songwriter of the soul and blues band The Holmes Brothers, has died.

Paul Kahn, Holmes' manager, says the 71-year-old musician died Friday at his home in Rosedale, Maryland.

Kahn says Holmes died of complications from pulmonary hypertension.

The three formed The Holmes Brothers in 1979.
